pullRequest.body:
Shortcuts for linearly ordered domains and/or continuous functions. As an example, I golf the existing `integrable_of_isBigO_exp_neg`.

Another example usage: https://github.com/AlexKontorovich/PrimeNumberTheoremAnd/blob/1909a40253607bd2df18a738fc504fe81b132974/PrimeNumberTheoremAnd/PerronFormula.lean#L414-L436

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
I wondered why you weren't doing `Ioi` as well as `Ici` versions, and then I realised the obvious generalisation of the statement is false :smile: Do you think it might be worth adding something like the following?
````
example (f : â„ â†’ â„) : IntegrableOn f (Ioi 0) â†” IntegrableAtFilter f atTop âˆ§
  IntegrableAtFilter f (ð“[>] 0) âˆ§ LocallyIntegrableOn f (Ioi 0) := sorry
````

> example (f : â„ â†’ â„) : IntegrableOn f (Ioi 0) â†” IntegrableAtFilter f atTop âˆ§
>   IntegrableAtFilter f (ð“[>] 0) âˆ§ LocallyIntegrableOn f (Ioi 0) := sorry

seems reasonable, added!

LGTM, thanks!

maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by loefflerd.

bors r+
Thanks!

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8552564284/job/23433923334)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8552564284/job/23433923639)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8552564284/job/23433924315)

I feel this use of `use` is a bit abusive. The intended purpose of `use` / `exists` is to prove existential statements `âˆƒ x, P x` by first exhibiting a specific `x` and then proving `P x`. It seems like a coincidence that it also works to prove `iff` statements. Using it this way is puzzling for readers, and might lead to annoying breakage if the implementations of the `use` / `exists` tactics change. (Others might see this differently from me, so feel free to ask on zulip for views.)
Changed all uses to `constructor`

This is unnecessary. By hypothesis `Î±` is a `LinearOrderedAddCommGroup`; so it can't be empty, it has to have a zero (indeed mathlib will happily synthesise a `Nonempty Î±` instance in this context if you ask it to). Similarly you don't have to invoke `Classical.arbitrary` to get your hands on an element of `Î±`, you can just use 0.
Nice catch, removed
Can you also remove the `isEmpty_or_nonempty Î±` lines, since they are not needed?
Of course, removed
Do you really need the `NoMinOrder` assumption here? I would guess the theorem is also true otherwise.

My thought is that if `a` is a bottom element, then the LHS is true and the RHS is `IntegrableOn {a} Î¼` from `IntegrableAtFilter f atBot Î¼`, since `{a}` would be, to my understanding, the principal of `atBot`. And then, I think if `IntegrableOn {a} Î¼` is true then we don't need this theorem at all since `IntegrableOn f (Iio a) Î¼ â†” IntegrableOn f (Iic a) Î¼`.

If itâ€™s true without the assumption, we should prove it in that generality, whether or not the corner case is mathematically interesting â€“ there is benefit in having a shorter and simpler set of hypotheses.

I guess what I'm saying is that I'm not convinced I can remove the assumption without adding `[MeasurableSingletonClass X]` and `Î¼ {a} â‰  âˆž` assumptions as per `integrableOn_singleton_iff`. 

I think, due to `IntegrableAtFilter f atBot Î¼ â†” IntegrableOn {âŠ¥} Î¼` in the bottom element case, that the true theorems would be:
- the theorem as stated
- a different theorem `IntegrableOn f (Iio a) Î¼ â†” IntegrableAtFilter f atBot Î¼ âˆ§ LocallyIntegrableOn f (Iio a) Î¼` which holds when `[MeasurableSingletonClass X]` and `Î¼ {a} â‰  âˆž`

At least, I haven't been successful in proving the `IntegrableOn f (Iio a) Î¼ â†’ IntegrableAtFilter f atBot Î¼` case without `[NoMinOrder X]`, although I haven't disproven it either. I could re-spell `[NoMinOrder X]` as `Set.Nonempty (Iio a)` but not eliminate it.

Ah, you're right, I had overlooked the case `Î¼ {a} = âˆž` (I thought you were assuming `Î¼` to be locally finite, but you're not). In this case, I'm happy with the current formulation. Sorry for the noise!

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: bounding integrals by asymptotics, part 2: corollaries
